Stem: Cat Max's eyes glow green in dark corners but not in lit areas. Why do Max's eyes appear to glow in dark corners?
Choices: A) Max's eyes produce their own light in the dark, B) Light reflects more strongly off a special layer in cat's eyes in the dark, C) Max's eyes absorb all light in dark areas creating a glow, D) The dark causes a chemical reaction in Max's eyes that produces green light
Scenario Justification: Real-world phenomenon (cat's glowing eyes) that students must explain. Observable and puzzling — requires reasoning about light behavior rather than simple recall.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for an observed phenomenon using understanding of light reflection. Engages Constructing Explanations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that light reflects off surfaces and that we see objects because of reflected light. Applied to a novel biological context (tapetum lucidum) at grade-appropriate level.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Cause and Effect — the special reflective layer (cause) produces the glowing appearance (effect). Students must reason about why the glow appears only in dark settings.
Key Recommendation: Good phenomenon-driven question about light reflection. Strengthen by adding a Part B asking students to explain why the glow is NOT visible in bright areas, requiring deeper causal reasoning about relative brightness.

Stem: A scientist studies wetland animals that have scales, can control their body temperature, and have specialized feet for moving through water and mud. Which pair of animals is the scientist MOST LIKELY studying?
Choices: A) Frogs and salamanders, B) Ducks and herons, C) Otters and beavers, D) Crocodiles and turtles
Scenario Justification: Provides a scientist context but the task is essentially classifying animals by traits — recall of which animals have scales and temperature regulation. Limited reasoning demand.
SEP Justification: Students match trait descriptions to organisms. Engages classification but at an identification level rather than deeper practice.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of animal structural features (scales, thermoregulation). Recall-level classification of organisms by traits.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Structure and Function (scales and feet serve functions) but students are not asked to reason about why these structures help the animals.
Key Recommendation: Essentially a classification recall question. Redesign to present an unfamiliar wetland organism with described traits and ask students to explain how each trait helps it survive in the wetland environment, engaging Structure and Function.

Stem: A young plant in a garden has received no rain for a week. Its leaves are drooping even though the soil is still damp below the surface. Why is this happening?
Choices: A) The plant's leaves are too heavy for the stem to support, B) The plant is getting too much sunlight causing the leaves to wilt, C) The root hairs are too damaged to absorb water effectively, D) The soil below the surface is too cold for the plant to use
Scenario Justification: Real-world scenario with a puzzling observation — soil is damp yet plant is wilting. Creates genuine cognitive demand because the obvious explanation (no water) is contradicted by the damp soil detail.
SEP Justification: Students must construct an explanation that reconciles conflicting evidence (damp soil + wilting). Engages Constructing Explanations from evidence. Requires evaluating multiple possible causes.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding plant structure and function — specifically how roots absorb water and transport it. Goes beyond recall to applied reasoning about root function.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (damaged roots cause inability to absorb water despite availability) and Structure and Function (root hairs as structures for water absorption). Students reason with both CCCs.
Key Recommendation: Strong question with a puzzling phenomenon that requires reconciling conflicting observations. Elevate by providing data about different soil conditions and root health and asking students to identify patterns in plant health.

Stem: Students are building a model of the digestive system. One student asks: Why can't we just skip some parts? Which answer BEST explains why all parts are needed?
Choices: A) All parts look the same and do the same job, B) The parts are only there to make the system look complete, C) Each part is connected but only the stomach does important work, D) Each part plays a different role; removing one stops the body from getting energy or removing waste
Scenario Justification: Embedded in a modeling activity context. Students reason about why a system model must include all components. Engages thinking about organ system interdependence.
SEP Justification: Students reason about a model and justify why components cannot be removed. Engages Developing and Using Models — reasoning about what makes a model complete and functional.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that the digestive system has multiple organs with distinct functions that work together. Goes beyond naming parts to understanding interdependence.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Systems and System Models — students must reason that each component plays a role in the system and removing one disrupts system function. Strong CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Good systems-thinking question embedded in a modeling context. Strengthen by providing a diagram of the digestive system model and asking students to predict what specific problem would occur if a particular part were removed.

Stem: An Arctic fox has thick white fur and small round ears in winter. How do these features help the fox survive in its environment?
Choices: A) Fur provides insulation and small ears minimize heat loss, B) White fur helps the fox see better in snow and small ears help it hear prey, C) Thick fur makes the fox heavier to stay grounded in wind and small ears reduce wind noise, D) White fur attracts mates and small ears make the fox more aerodynamic
Scenario Justification: Describes a real organism with specific adaptations but the question is a fairly standard structure-function matching task. Limited puzzlement or uncertainty.
SEP Justification: Students explain how structures serve survival functions. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level — selecting the correct function for given structures.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding how body structures (fur thickness, ear size) relate to survival in cold environments. Applied understanding of structure and function in organisms.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Structure and Function — thick fur insulates, small ears reduce surface area for heat loss. Students must connect structure to function explicitly.
Key Recommendation: Standard structure-function question. Elevate by providing comparative data about Arctic fox winter vs. summer traits (ear size, fur thickness, color) and asking students to explain the pattern and predict what would happen if the fox kept summer traits in winter.

Stem: When food is placed in the kitchen, a cat comes running from another room. How does the cat know food has been placed?
Choices: A) The cat sees the food through the walls, B) The cat feels vibrations from the food being placed, C) The cat hears the owner calling even though no one called, D) The cat's nose sends electrical signals to the brain about the food smell
Scenario Justification: Real-world scenario with an observable phenomenon (cat detecting food from another room). Students must reason about sensory processing — not just which sense, but the mechanism of signal transmission to the brain.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation involving sensory processing mechanisms. Goes beyond naming the sense (smell) to explaining the signal pathway. Engages Constructing Explanations.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that sensory organs detect stimuli and transmit information to the brain as electrical signals. Applied understanding of information processing in organisms.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Cause and Effect (smell molecules cause receptor activation causing brain signals) but the causal chain is embedded in the answer rather than requiring explicit reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Good that it requires understanding the mechanism (electrical signals to brain) rather than just naming the sense. Strengthen by asking a Part B about what would happen if the cat's olfactory nerves were damaged — requiring causal chain reasoning.

Stem: A student studying sedimentary rocks in a canyon observes fossils from bottom to top: sea creatures, fish, swamp plants, dry-land plants. Which BEST explains this sequence?
Choices: A) The animals migrated from the ocean to land over time, B) The environment changed from ocean to swamp to dry land over time, C) A flood carried all the fossils and deposited them randomly, D) The organisms evolved to live on land instead of water
Scenario Justification: Presents a real geological scenario with sequential fossil evidence in rock layers. Students must reason about environmental change over time using fossil evidence. Genuine analytical demand.
SEP Justification: Students analyze fossil evidence across layers to construct an explanation of environmental change. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Constructing Explanations from evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that fossils in rock layers provide evidence of past environments and that the sequence reflects environmental change over geological time. Applied reasoning.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (fossil sequence reveals a pattern of environmental change) and Stability and Change (environments change over time as evidenced by fossils). Students must recognize the pattern to answer.
Key Recommendation: Strong evidence-based reasoning question. Elevate by asking a follow-up: What would you predict fossils in a layer ABOVE the dry-land plants might look like if the pattern continued? This would deepen pattern-based reasoning.

Stem: A coastal cliff has caves and openings carved into its bottom by waves. The upper part of the cliff remains unchanged. Why is the bottom different from the top?
Choices: A) The bottom rocks are softer than the top rocks, B) Animals at the bottom have dug holes into the cliff, C) Continuous wave action breaks down and carries away rock particles at the base, D) The bottom of the cliff is older and has had more time to erode naturally
Scenario Justification: Real coastal phenomenon with an observable contrast (eroded bottom vs. intact top). Students must explain the differential erosion pattern using understanding of wave erosion processes.
SEP Justification: Students construct an explanation for a geologic observation. Engages Constructing Explanations — must connect wave action to the observed erosion pattern at the cliff base.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that water (waves) weathers and erodes rock through physical processes over time. Applied understanding of Earth surface processes.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (wave action causes erosion at the base) and Patterns (differential erosion creates a pattern). Students must reason about why erosion is concentrated at the bottom.
Key Recommendation: Good causal reasoning question about differential erosion. Strengthen by providing diagrams showing the cliff at different time points and asking students to predict future changes and explain the pattern.

Stem: A coastal cliff is changing rapidly. It faces the open ocean, undergoes freeze/thaw cycles, and has cracks where plants are growing. Why is this cliff changing more rapidly than other cliffs?
Choices: A) The cliff is made of a special type of rock that dissolves quickly, B) Multiple types of weathering and erosion are working together on the cliff, C) The cliff is very old and has been eroding for millions of years, D) The plants on the cliff are the primary cause of its rapid erosion
Scenario Justification: Presents a complex scenario with multiple interacting factors (wave erosion, freeze/thaw, biological weathering). Students must synthesize multiple weathering processes rather than identify just one. Higher cognitive demand.
SEP Justification: Students must analyze multiple factors and synthesize them into a unified explanation. Engages Constructing Explanations at a higher level — requires reasoning about how multiple processes interact to accelerate change.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding multiple weathering and erosion processes (mechanical, chemical, biological) and their combined effects. Applied at a synthesis level.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Cause and Effect (multiple causes produce accelerated change) and Systems thinking (multiple interacting processes as a system). Students must reason about interaction effects.
Key Recommendation: One of the stronger questions on the test. The multi-factor scenario creates genuine complexity. Could elevate further by asking students to rank which factor contributes most and justify their reasoning with evidence.

Stem: A geologist is studying a topographic map of a coastal area. The contour lines are widely spaced inland but become very close together near the ocean. What landform does this pattern of lines indicate?
Choices: A) A flat sandy beach gradually sloping into the ocean, B) A river delta with many branching waterways, C) A gentle rolling hillside leading to the ocean, D) A coastal cliff with a steep drop to the ocean
Scenario Justification: Students must interpret a topographic map pattern — widely spaced lines indicate gentle slope, closely spaced indicate steep terrain. Requires understanding of topographic map conventions and applying them to identify a landform.
SEP Justification: Students analyze and interpret data from a topographic map representation. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data — map reading requires practice-level reasoning.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding topographic map conventions (contour line spacing indicates steepness) and applying that knowledge to identify a specific landform. Applied understanding.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns — students must recognize the pattern in contour line spacing and connect it to slope steepness. Pattern recognition is central to answering correctly.
Key Recommendation: Good map interpretation question requiring pattern recognition. Strengthen by providing the actual topographic map image and asking students to draw a profile view of the landscape, making the map-to-terrain connection explicit.

Stem: Scientists are mapping a volcano in Hawaii. Which measurement would be MOST useful to understand the shape and steepness of the volcano?
Choices: A) The distance between height measurement lines (contour intervals), B) The color of the rocks on the volcano surface, C) The temperature of the lava flowing from the volcano, D) The number of plants growing on the volcano slopes
Scenario Justification: Connects to real scientific work (volcano mapping in Hawaii). Students must reason about which type of measurement provides information about shape and steepness.
SEP Justification: Students select the most useful measurement for a given purpose. Engages Planning and Carrying Out Investigations at a basic level — choosing appropriate measurements. However, the task is selection rather than design.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that contour interval spacing reveals information about slope steepness and landform shape. Applied understanding of topographic measurement.
CCC Justification: Implicitly engages Patterns (contour patterns reveal shape) and Scale, Proportion, and Quantity (measurement intervals) but students are not asked to reason deeply with these CCCs.
Key Recommendation: Reasonable measurement selection question. Strengthen by providing actual contour data from two different volcanoes and asking students to compare their shapes and explain which is steeper and why.

Stem: A mountain community needs to reduce damage from soil movements up to 15 feet deep. Three solutions are available: retaining walls (hold soil 20 ft deep, 4 months to build), drainage systems (redirect water away from slopes, 1 month to build), vegetation planting (holds soil 10 ft deep, 2 years to grow). Which combination BEST addresses the problem?
Image/Diagram Description: Table or description of three solutions with specifications
Choices: A) Vegetation planting and drainage systems, B) Retaining walls and vegetation planting, C) Retaining walls and drainage systems, D) All three solutions together
Scenario Justification: Strong engineering design problem with explicit constraints (15 ft depth requirement, time considerations) and multiple solution options with trade-offs. Students must evaluate solutions against criteria. Real-world context.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate and compare solutions against criteria and constraints. Engages Designing Solutions — requires analyzing trade-offs and selecting the best combination. High practice demand.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering design principles — evaluating solutions against specified constraints. Students must reason about why vegetation (10 ft) is insufficient for 15 ft soil movements.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (soil movement causes damage; solutions cause stabilization) and Systems thinking (solutions work together as a system). Also engages Scale, Proportion, and Quantity (depth specifications).
Key Recommendation: Excellent constraint-based engineering question with quantitative reasoning. One of the strongest on the test. Elevate by asking a Part B: Why is vegetation planting alone insufficient? — requiring explicit constraint analysis.

Stem: Maria's business is near a flood zone. She considers two options: permanent flood barriers (6 ft protection, cannot be removed) vs. deployable barriers (4 ft protection, can be stored when not needed). Her priorities are protection AND minimizing environmental disruption. Which solution BEST meets her priorities?
Choices: A) Permanent barriers because they provide taller protection, B) Permanent barriers because they are always ready, C) Deployable barriers because they are cheaper, D) Deployable barriers because they have less permanent impact on natural drainage
Scenario Justification: Strong engineering design problem with competing priorities (protection level vs. environmental impact). Students must weigh trade-offs between two solutions with different strengths. Real-world context with genuine decision-making.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate competing solutions against multiple criteria (protection AND environmental impact). Engages Designing Solutions and Engaging in Argument — must justify why one trade-off is preferable. High practice demand.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding engineering design trade-offs — solutions that excel on one criterion may compromise another. Students must reason about environmental disruption as a design constraint.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (permanent barriers cause ongoing environmental disruption) and Systems thinking (drainage systems as interconnected with flood barriers). Students reason about system-level impacts.
Key Recommendation: Strong trade-off analysis question. Students must prioritize competing criteria. Elevate by asking students to explain what situations might make permanent barriers the better choice — requiring deeper contextual reasoning.

Stem: Three balls roll down ramps. Ball A travels 10 meters in 10 seconds. Ball B travels 12 meters in 4 seconds. Ball C travels 24 meters in 6 seconds. Which ball has the MOST energy based on its speed?
Choices: A) Ball A because it traveled the longest time, B) Ball B because it traveled the shortest distance, C) Ball C because it has the highest speed at approximately 4 m/s, D) All balls have equal energy because they all rolled down ramps
Scenario Justification: Provides quantitative data requiring speed calculations. Students must compute speed (distance/time) for each ball and connect speed to energy. Multi-step reasoning required.
SEP Justification: Students analyze quantitative data to determine speed and relate it to energy. Engages Analyzing and Interpreting Data and Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the relationship between speed and kinetic energy. Students must apply the concept that faster objects have more energy. Applied with computational component.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (speed causes greater energy) and Scale, Proportion, and Quantity (quantitative comparison of speeds). Students must use proportional reasoning.
Key Recommendation: Good quantitative reasoning question connecting speed to energy. Strengthen by adding mass data for each ball and asking students to consider both speed AND mass in determining energy — a more complete analysis.

Stem: Two identical containers of water both start at 30 degrees C. One is placed near a radiator at 45 degrees C and the other near an ice bucket at 0 degrees C. What happens to the thermal energy in each container?
Choices: A) Both containers gain thermal energy from their surroundings, B) The container near the radiator gains energy while the one near the ice bucket loses energy, C) Both containers lose thermal energy to their surroundings, D) Neither container changes because they are identical
Scenario Justification: Sets up a comparative scenario with two containers at the same starting temperature in different thermal environments. Students must apply understanding of heat transfer direction to both situations simultaneously.
SEP Justification: Students analyze two thermal situations and predict energy transfer direction for each. Engages Constructing Explanations — must apply heat transfer principles to two contrasting cases.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that thermal energy transfers from warmer to cooler objects. Applied to two parallel scenarios requiring independent analysis of each.
CCC Justification: Directly engages Energy and Matter — energy flows from hot to cold. Also engages Cause and Effect — temperature difference causes energy transfer in a specific direction. Students reason with energy flow.
Key Recommendation: Good comparative thermal energy question. Strengthen by asking students to predict the approximate final temperatures of both containers and explain the pattern of energy transfer over time.

Stem: David has a toy car that runs on batteries. Which observation shows that electrical energy is being converted to motion energy?
Choices: A) The car's headlights turn on when the switch is flipped, B) The car moves across the floor when turned on, C) The car makes a buzzing sound when the motor runs, D) The car's body feels slightly warm after running for a while
Scenario Justification: Simple scenario about a battery-powered car. The question asks students to identify which observation demonstrates a specific energy conversion, but the answer is fairly obvious.
SEP Justification: Students identify an observation that demonstrates a specific energy conversion. Engages basic observation-to-concept connection but limited analytical demand.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of energy conversion from electrical to kinetic. Fairly straightforward identification of the correct energy form.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (electrical energy causes motion) at a basic level. Students must connect the energy input to the observable output.
Key Recommendation: The correct answer is obvious — motion energy is demonstrated by motion. Redesign to provide data about the car's behavior (distance, speed, temperature, light output) and ask students to trace ALL energy conversions occurring, engaging Energy and Matter more deeply.

Stem: Maya stirs her hot chocolate with a metal spoon. After a few minutes, the handle of the spoon becomes warm. How is the energy transferred from the hot chocolate to the spoon handle?
Choices: A) The metal spoon conducts heat from the hot chocolate through the spoon to the handle, B) The hot chocolate radiates heat directly to the handle through the air, C) The handle absorbs heat from the surrounding air that was warmed by the hot chocolate, D) The hot chocolate evaporates and the steam warms the handle
Scenario Justification: Real-world phenomenon that students experience regularly. Requires explaining the mechanism of heat transfer through a solid material (conduction). Observable and relatable.
SEP Justification: Students select the correct explanation for heat transfer. Engages Constructing Explanations at a basic level but the answer is somewhat recall-dependent (conduction through metal).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding thermal conduction — heat energy transfers through direct contact in solid materials. Applied to a specific real-world context.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (contact with hot liquid causes heat transfer through metal) and Energy and Matter (energy flows through the spoon material). Basic CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Good real-world context but largely tests recall of conduction. Strengthen by comparing a metal spoon to a wooden spoon and asking students to predict and explain the difference in heat transfer — engaging Structure and Function.

Stem: When you rub your hands together quickly, they feel warm. What type of energy is being converted to heat?
Choices: A) Light energy from the room, B) Sound energy from the friction, C) Chemical energy stored in your muscles, D) Energy of motion from moving your hands
Scenario Justification: Simple everyday observation about friction and heat. Minimal scenario depth — the question is essentially identifying the energy conversion.
SEP Justification: Students identify an energy conversion. Limited practice engagement — selects from options rather than constructing an explanation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that kinetic energy (motion) converts to thermal energy (heat) through friction. Basic recall of energy conversion.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (motion causes heat through friction) at a basic level. Students identify the cause but don't reason deeply about the mechanism.
Key Recommendation: Basic energy conversion recall. Redesign by providing experimental data about hand-rubbing speed vs. temperature increase and asking students to identify the pattern and predict outcomes at different speeds.

Stem: A student is exploring ways to charge a phone while camping. On a sunny day with little wind, which energy source would be MOST efficient?
Choices: A) A small solar panel, B) A small wind turbine, C) A hand-crank generator, D) A thermoelectric generator using campfire heat
Scenario Justification: Real-world engineering/resource scenario with specific environmental constraints (sunny, little wind). Students must match the energy source to the available conditions.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate energy sources against environmental conditions. Engages basic evaluation but the answer is fairly obvious given the stated conditions (sunny + no wind = solar).
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of renewable energy sources and their dependence on environmental conditions. Basic application — matching source to conditions.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (environmental conditions cause certain energy sources to work better) at a basic level. Limited depth of CCC reasoning required.
Key Recommendation: The answer is too obvious given the scenario constraints. Redesign by presenting conditions where multiple sources could work (partly sunny, moderate wind) and asking students to analyze trade-offs with data about energy output.

Stem: A small coastal town is planning a new electricity generation facility. Which option would be LEAST harmful to the marine ecosystem and air quality?
Choices: A) An offshore oil drilling platform, B) Solar panels installed on existing buildings, C) A coal-fired power plant near the shore, D) A natural gas facility on the beach
Scenario Justification: Real-world community decision about energy with environmental criteria (marine ecosystem, air quality). Students must evaluate options against specified criteria.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate multiple energy options against environmental criteria. Engages Engaging in Argument from Evidence — must reason about environmental impacts of each option.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding the environmental impacts of different energy sources — fossil fuel pollution vs. renewable energy benefits. Applied understanding of human impacts on Earth systems.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (energy sources cause different environmental impacts) but the reasoning is fairly straightforward. Limited depth of CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Good environmental reasoning question but the correct answer is somewhat obvious. Strengthen by adding more nuanced options (e.g., offshore wind which helps air quality but may affect marine life) and asking students to analyze trade-offs.

Stem: Two waves are created on ropes. Wave A has tall peaks that are far apart. Wave B has short peaks that are close together. What do these observations tell us about the two waves?
Choices: A) Wave A has greater amplitude and longer wavelength than Wave B, B) Wave A has greater amplitude and shorter wavelength than Wave B, C) Wave B has greater amplitude and longer wavelength than Wave A, D) Both waves have the same amplitude but different wavelengths
Scenario Justification: Students must interpret visual descriptions of wave properties. The question describes wave features and asks students to match them to correct terminology. Limited scenario depth.
SEP Justification: Students interpret wave descriptions and apply wave property terminology. Basic data interpretation — matching descriptions to terms rather than analyzing data.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding wave properties — amplitude (peak height) and wavelength (distance between peaks). Applied understanding of wave terminology and characteristics.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (wave properties as observable patterns) at a basic level. Students recognize patterns in wave descriptions but don't reason deeply with CCC.
Key Recommendation: Largely a vocabulary/definition matching question. Strengthen by providing wave diagrams with measurements and asking students to predict how changing amplitude affects energy transfer — connecting wave properties to function.

Stem: At a construction site on a hillside, soil is washing into a nearby lake during rainstorms. Which solution would BEST reduce sediment entering the lake while still allowing water to flow?
Choices: A) Building a concrete dam across the stream leading to the lake, B) Covering the entire hillside with plastic sheeting, C) Digging a deep trench around the construction site, D) Installing silt fences along strategic areas of the hillside
Scenario Justification: Real-world engineering problem with dual criteria (reduce sediment AND allow water flow). Students must evaluate solutions against both constraints. Relevant environmental context.
SEP Justification: Students evaluate multiple solutions against specified criteria and constraints. Engages Designing Solutions — must reason about which option meets both requirements simultaneously.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding erosion control methods and engineering design principles — solutions must address the problem without creating new problems. Applied engineering reasoning.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (rain causes sediment runoff; silt fences cause sediment capture) and Systems thinking (water flow and sediment as interconnected system components). Students must reason about system-level effects.
Key Recommendation: Good constraint-based engineering question. Strengthen by asking students to explain why a concrete dam (option A) fails the second criterion — requiring explicit constraint analysis and trade-off reasoning.
